It's so surprising to feel my muscles. I did pretty much everything until minute 11. I noticed I was getting low on energy. In the past this has been when I'd stop the video and go on to my day, but the truth is that the sour taste of having not finished a video would stay with me. For some reason (thankfully), I remembered that this is about time and breath first of all. So I lay down on my back, my left hand on my heart and my right hand on my belly, and just breathed. Did some ratios for a bit. Then sat up and continued breathing. I felt good. I joined Adriene for the last bit: knocking on heaven's door, and I was up on my feet to say 'Namaste' back to her.

Today's discovery is not only that how I move matters, as Adriene says, but how I end also matters. Do I end with guilt, with a feeling of defeat, because of my perfectionism? Or do I recognise truthfully when my energy dips, my joy dissolves, and choose to reconnect to myself exactly as I am instead of being angry for not being other than what I am. And then, humbly, join for the end. Not to fake that I've done it all, but to mark that I've carved time out for myself, from beginning to end, from joy to doubt and back to joy -- exactly as I was in my rollercoaster of emotions. Knocking on heaven's door I realised this was not only some time for myself to breathe, but that actually my muscles felt good and sore.

This was a workout. This was a meditation. This was growth. This was a win, all around.

@Shade On A Cool Day Same here! I was on a really good gym routine before the lockdown but I actually didn't go about the rest of my habits the right way... I was indulging in way too many treats and eating when I just wanted to "numb out". I justified it with hitting the gym. My weight loss and muscle gain were completely stalled because (as I'm reflecting on it now) I didn't change my diet drastically enough and wasn't taking care of my mind as I was taking care of my body.

I started doing Yoga with Adriene daily and several other workouts on Youtube when quarantine started. I found that I also needed to track my calories to keep myself accountable with my diet. (I use Sparkpeople.com, it's free ;-) ) I also meditate now daily and I CANNOT recommend it enough... meditation has quieted my brain in the way food used to, without the guilt.

I have a checklist of daily healthy habits to keep myself accountable. It's just a daily list I made in my planner and I check them off each day. I've been doing that since March and I've lost 20 pounds since the start of the pandemic. I no longer am focused on weight loss but for strength building and maintenance.
